title: CNN host John Avlon slammed for 'right-wing terrorists' segment on 9/11
text:
CNN anchor and political analyst John Avlon came under fire Wednesday after he warned viewers about the dangers of “right-wing” terrorism on the 18th anniversary of 9/11.

Hosting CNN’s “New Day,” Mr. Avlon gave a “reality check” monologue claiming that “white nationalist terrorism” is similar in many ways to radical Islamic terrorism and should face the same amount of attention. He cited the gunman who recently targeted Latinos at an El Paso, Texas, Walmart and the anti-Semitic mass shootings at synagogues in San Diego and Pittsburgh in the past year.

“These terror suspects echoed white supremacist talk about ‘replacement,’ hatred towards Jews, immigrants, refugees, and that’s not including the would-be attacks we’ve seen thwarted by law enforcement,” Mr. Avlon said.

“Here’s a startling statistic: Since 9/11, right-wing terrorists have killed more people in the United States than jihadist terrorists, according to New America,” he said, citing the public policy think tank.

“There are some folks for their own political purposes would like to keep the focus on only one form of political violence over another, but that would be unwise, because we don’t have the luxury of choosing which threats we face,” he continued. “And there’s a case to be made that these threats actually echo each other. They’re weaponized versions of tribalism, motivated by fear and finding identity in their hatred of the ‘other.’”

Mr. Avlon ended his speech by urging Americans to not let “hate win or fear define us.”

The segment received a barrage of backlash on social media, mostly by conservatives who were offended by the timing. Many argued that it was inappropriate to hype right-wing extremism when it was Islamic terrorists who attacked the country on Sept. 11, 2001, and killed nearly 3,000 people.

Mr. Avlon responded to the outrage by re-posting an essay he wrote after 9/11 about the resilience of New York City.

“One of my rules is that you don’t feed the trolls, but for folks like the guy who emailed today that he wished I was killed in the World Trade Center, might want to read this essay about 9/11 that I wrote called The Resilient City,” he tweeted Wednesday night.
